title: Contemporary American Sculpture

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of tempera on paper mounted to hardboard.

description: In this work, Ben Shahn blended fact and fiction to offer a pointed commentary on the inclusions and exclusions of the art world. This enigmatic composition features eight known sculptures by leading artists of the day that were all displayed at a 1940 exhibition at the Whitney Museum. Three large, unframed painted images on the back walls of the gallery appear to be part of the show, but they were not actual paintings. Instead, they derive from Shahn’s photographs of working-class people around the United States, which he had taken while employed by the federal government as part of the New Deal, an economic program intended to revitalize the economy during the Great Depression. The invented works serve as portals to different worlds. The figures portrayed in them are positioned to see into the gallery but they are excluded from the “real” space of the museum and the modern art on view because of race, class, and geography.
medium_display: Tempera on paper mounted to hardboard
inscriptions: Signed and inscribed recto, bottom-right corner, in black pigment: Ben Shahn ‘40

publication_history: Whitney Museum of American Art, Annual Exhibition of Contemporary American Sculpture, Watercolors, Drawings, and Prints, exh. cat. (New York: Whitney Museum of American Art, 1941), no. 157. Dorothy C. Miller and Alfred H. Barr, Jr., American Realists and Magic Realists, exh. cat. (New York: Museum of Modern Art, 1943), 52–53, 67, no. 225. The Downtown Gallery, Shahn Paintings, exh. cat. (New York: The Downtown Gallery, 1944), no. 13. Whitney Museum of American Art, Annual Exhibition of Contemporary American Sculpture, Watercolors, Drawings, and Prints, exh. cat. (New York: Whitney Museum of American Art, 1944), no. 135. University of Minnesota, 40 American Painters, 1940–1950, exh. cat. (Minneapolis: The Gallery, 1951), n.p., no. 65 (ill.). James Thrall Soby, Ben Shahn: Paintings (New York: George Braziller, 1963), no. 18. Jeffrey Richmond-Moll (ed.), Extra Ordinary: Magic, Mystery and Imagination in American Realism, exh. cat. (Athens, GA: Georgia Museum of Art, 2021), 213, cat. 57 (ill.). Dr. Jeffrey Richmond-Moll and Dr. Beth Harris, "Ben Shahn, Contemporary American Sculpture," in Smarthistory, July 8, 2021, accessed January 18, 2023, https://smarthistory.org/ben-shahn-contemporary-american-sculpture/.
exhibition_history: New York, Julien Levy Gallery, Paintings by Ben Shahn, May 7–29, 1940. New York, Whitney Museum of American Art, Annual Exhibition of Contemporary American Sculpture, Watercolors, Drawings, and Prints, Jan. 15–Feb. 9, 1941, no. 157. New York, Museum of Modern Art, Americans 1943: Realists and Magic-Realists, Feb. 10–Mar. 21, 1943, no. 225 (not exhibited). New York, The Downtown Gallery, Ben Shahn: Paintings in Tempera, Nov. 14–Dec. 2, 1944, no. 13. New York, Whitney Museum of American Art, Annual Exhibition of Contemporary American Painting, Nov. 14–Dec. 12, 1944, no. 135. Art Institute of Chicago, 5th Annual Exhibition of the Society for Contemporary Art, Jan. 25–Feb. 18, 1945, no cat. Minneapolis, University Gallery, University of Minnesota, 40 American Painters, 1940–1950, June 4–Aug. 30, 1951, no. 65 (ill.). Athens, GA, Georgia Museum of Art, Extra Ordinary: Magic, Mystery and Imagination in American Realism, Feb. 27–June 13, 2021, cat. 57 (ill.).
provenance_text: The artist, until at least 1945 [Chicago 1945]; with The Downtown Gallery, New York [this and the following, according to Horseman Foundation cataloging record, accessed Jan. 23, 2023, copy in curatorial object file]; sold to Joseph Kaufman (1911-2001), New York, 1946; by descent to his sons, Arthur Kaufman and Marshall Kaufman, 2001 [email from Arthur Kaufman, Dec. 16, 2022, copy in curatorial object file]; sold to private collection, New York, c. 2001 [this and the following, email from Jonathan Boos, Dec. 16, 2022, copy in curatorial object file]; sold to Jonathan and Sheri Boos, Bloomfield, MI, 2014; sold to John and Susan Horseman, St. Louis, MO, 2017; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2023.
